top_comment.text: fish schooling it the back round hahah﻿
top_comment.author: smallies7834

top_comment.text:
You see how he keeps his rod up and pressure on the fish. That's how u keep 
from losing fish. Too many guys think keep the rod down to keep the bass 
from jumping. You actually put slack and give the bad the advantage when u 
do that﻿
top_comment.author: Dmgolfer22

comments.text:
You can still keep pressure on the fish and play it off to the side. 
Hauling them up will give them to chance to jump or head shake at the 
surface and more likely to lose them that way then you are playing them to 
the side. I don't like straight down I go off to the side at about waist 
level. But in essence pressure on the line is pressure on the line no 
matter which way you put it there. Playing the fish is another story.
comments.author: Ryan Costello

comments.text: Its fun when the fish jumps who cares if it jumps
comments.author: daniel gomes

captions.text:
Hey guys we’re here, I can’t believe it’s
the last week of October, on Lake Eufaula,

we’re about an hour and half from my house
and I haven’t fished a whole lot of tournaments

on this lake but the few tournaments that
I have fished have been really good and it’s

always been catching and cranking them on
this main river ledges. I tell ya what I figured

out several years ago is there is a lot of
timber in this lake and it grows on the sides

of these ledges on the main river and these
fish will get out here and suspend in that

timber. So we are going to go out and crank
some of the top of this timber and see if

we can’t catch some of these big ole Chattanooga
river full of bass.

Well what we’ve got here is a little bar
out here on the river channel and it has a

little patch of timber on the end of it and
these fish like to get out here and suspend

over top of that timber in the fall, especially
on these cloudy days. And all we gotta do

is get the Spro Papa 70 off of that timber
and trigger one to bite. Once you get the

first one to bite, it’s on then. You usually
catch three or four and more with three or

four casts in a row. That’s what we are
trying to do, get one of these fish to bite…..get
them fired up.

There’s one! I don’t know if he’s any
good but he sure did crush it. Ah a little
fish…. A little bity spot.

There’s a big one. Boy he crushed it. What
have we got!? A stripper. Oh we’ve got 2!

Check this out! Oh the other one came off.
I don’t know if you all could see that but

right at the boat, we had 2 of these. And
one of them come off which that happens sometimes.

But you know I sit here and threw and threw
and threw and I’ve been throwing here for

5 minutes in the same place and once you get
them fired up, they all start to bit it. A
nice little chunk.

I’ve got it going right now guys; just a
little one but there is a pretty good school

down there right now. The main thing is when
you get them fired up like that, hurry up

and get your bait back in the water and keep
them going, and try not to let them rest.

Keep them Fired up. Just like that! Another
little guy. A spotted bass.

Oh what have we got! This is a big one guys!
He crushed it. Oh it’s big, ole head shaker,

there we go! Smoked that Fat Papa. Favorite
way to catch them! Hahaha, look at that! Lake
Eufaula in the fall, Fat Papa 70.

Let’s see, what have we got here. Must be
a little white bass, yep a white bass. I tell

you when you catch these little white bass;
I know sometimes they are a nuisance. And

Kind of messes with your school a little bit,
messes with your mind. But some of the biggest

schools that I’ve ever found is mixed with
those white bass. Keep that in mind, they

are there to feed on the same things also.
Even when you are using your electronics and

looking for these big schools of fish, look
for them white bass. They always tell you
where a feeding place is.

You know I will keep grinding on this school
as long as I can. Keep my bait in the water

and when they slow down, the first thing that
I try to do is change colors. Like right now

I’m throwing a lavender shad, Fat Papa 70
and we have low light conditions, I’ll probably

put a tropical shad on after this just to
show them something different. Which is a

real bright chartreuse and blue back. You
just wanna keep showing them different colors,

different angles and I even change up the
line size occasionally which will give the

bait a little deeper grinding action and just
something different. Just keep changing it

up on them. Keep working on them. Use a stop
and go retrieve sometimes a steady retrieve,
you just gotta feed it to them.

See how I slowed it down that time real slow;
oh we have got a giant on guys! Change your

retrieve, that’s what it’s all about,
doing something different. This is a mule.

I’m telling you this is a big fish bait.
You’re not going to believe this fish right

here. I can see that he is a toad. I don’t
know how big he is….here he comes. This

could be a 10. Could be just a monster. Here
he comes, look at that guys. Ohhh I love doing

this! Oh I cannot get my hands around him!
Look at that! Whoa! What do ya all think about

that! ….. laughing….. Look at that plug
in his mouth! That is a hammer. Hey we’re

fishing for fun and I am out here shaking,
that is what this is all about. That fish

will go to 9 pounds easy; look at how fat
he is. Who says Lake Eufaula an’it in good
shape.

title: 9-pound Bass Caught on Fat Papa 70 Crankbait
